body.p:
JACOB VOORSANGER,
EDITOR JEWISH SOUTH,
HOUSTON, TEXAS.

Rev. S. Morais
My dear Sir

I am in the receipt of your postal
card and of proofs of your article, both of which
reached me last Monday. The railroad track of the
St. Louis & Iron Mountain R. R. which carries the Tex,
as mails is entirely submerged, owing to the Mississippi
floods in Arkansas and on that account mails are con
stantly delayed and in consequence your article
appeared in the J. S. before I could send a corrected
proof to New Orleans. Fortunately not much harm
is done; the article has appeared almost entirely free
from errors, but the correction requested could not be
made and had I been in time your article would
have had the place of honor, the editorial page,
whereas now it was printed on the inside. I hope
that any incorrection which has crept in will not
be placed to my credit.

Permit me to express my thanks to you for the
honor you have conferred upon me by answer,

ing my article. I wrote as I felt, but I did not over
look the respect due you as our leader and teacher
I wanted to be informed, not to criticize. And I am
very glad that you accepted my article in that spi
rit. Now will you pardon me, if I insist that even
your reply has failed to satisfy me? You certainly
make strong points, but the main point—permit me--
remains unanswered. I will only make one illustra
tion: Bernstein, a German rationalist, claims that
the whole of Genesis covering the history of Jacob
and Joseph was written at the court of Joroboam[?] I
for political purposes. The points he makes are very
strong. The writer makes Joseph Jacob's best beloved
son to prove that the kingdom of Israel is God's
favorite. He depicts Joseph's sufferings to prove
that already in olden times there was division
between Joseph and the rest. He makes Jacob
sacrifice at Beth El, to prove that Beth El was
a place of worship before ever Jerusalem was
thought of. Rachel—Joseph's mother is Jacob's
best beloved wife. Judah, the representative
and archi-type of the other kingdom is made

JACOB VOORSANGER,
EDITOR JEWISH SOUTH,
HOUSTON, TEXAS.

a whoremaster and adulterer, and even his
sons are the offspring of adultery from which
the seed of David has sprung—this to prove
the low origin of the royal family. Now, if I accept
these facts, what becomes of the logical or even
historical connection of the book of Genesis?
Graetz proves that most of the Levitical laws
were inserted in Torath Kohanim by the Kene,
set Haggedola in imitation of the Parsee
laws. The same author makes Solemon res,
ponsible for the [?] [Hebrew] in Leviticus, what
must I think of all this? I assure you
Robertson Smith is not the worst enemy with
whom conservative religion has to contend, And
I am still at a loss to know how all these
facts can be disproven, or how an acceptance
thereof can be reconcilable with conservatism.
I am sadly perplexed, have still more become
so since the publication of your "talk." I
do not mean to infer that I am unsettled
in my private opinions on these subjects. I

have for several years past studied the subject
carefully and I may say prayerfully, but I dare
not present my private judgment to my charges
unless I have sufficient argument at my com
mand to prove that conservative, historical
Judaism stands above any consideration of
that nature. These arguments I thought to elicit
from you. Will you keep me in my endeavors?
I should be so thankful, That I have long ago
come back to my conservative principles the
Jewish South may witness. That paper is pledged
to conservative Judaism, and though my form
of worship is modern, my preaching is as
conservative as yours. I would ask your
permission to continue this controversy
in the press. Nothing but good can come of it.
We need an awakening of public sentiment
in favor of conservatism, and by the dashing
of opinions it can be done. Rationalism
and radicalism are making sad havoc
with Judaism, and hardly a line is written
from our side. If my God gives me health

JACOB VOORSANGER,
EDITOR JEWISH SOUTH,
HOUSTON, TEXAS.

and strength to continue my work I shall not
remain idle. I have learned to speak and to
write plainly and forcibly, and I intend to do
my share of the work. We have an important
point in our favor, to wit, that the American
religious tendency is decidedly conservative,
and with proper and systematic work, The A,
merican Jewish Synagogue will step over
Kohler and Adler into the arms of Moses
and the prophets. Now, if you will consent
to continue this controversy, it would delight
me, not from any selfish motive but [Hebrew]
and I beg you to inform me of your decision
on the subject.

Thanks for your kind inquiries after the health
of myself and family. I have been quite sick
for the last four weeks, was in fact confined
to my bed, but now I feel strong and well again

and ready for work. Mrs. V. and the children are
enjoying exceptional good health for which I am
duly thankful. Your little namesake is now a "wee
toddler" of 21 months old, and begins to prattle in
all imaginable dialects. He has another little brother
born two months ago, which makes the number
of my children five and charges me with additi
onal responsibilities. How the years toll[?] on. Eight
and a half years ago I was a youngster, without a
single responsibility and before I am thirty I am
a father of five children, and carrying more res
ponsibilities than I think sometimes I am able
to bear. Many thanks for your good opinion con
cerning my usefulness. I aim at doing a man's work
and I beg to assure you, that at this period of my
career I am as sensitive and anxious to de
serve your confidence and good wishes as I
was ever before. With my respectful regards to Miss
Morais and the children and my love to yourself
and hoping to be favored with an early answer
I remain Faithfully yours
